turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hello? Hello. Um, before I go any further, can I confirm your name and your date of birth?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, yeah. Uh my name is April, and I'm fifty.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You're fifty, OK. April, how can I help you this afternoon?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Well I've just been having this like, cough, for quite a few days. And my nose is running. Um and it's just been super annoying, and it's not going away.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>, OK. When did it all start?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh I think it started like maybe, a bit less than a week ago. Like maybe, maybe five or six days ago.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And you mentioned a couple of things there. You mentioned a cough. You mentioned a bit of a runny nose. Is that right?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Let's focus on your cough first. Can you tell me a bit more about your cough?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, it's just so continuous. It's really, really frustrating. It's quite dry. And it's just all day, it like keeps me up at night as well, which is really annoying.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So it's a dry cough. So you're not bringing up any <UNIN/>, you're not bringing up any mucky, ohh I can hear that, yeah. Um you're not bringing up any uh, mucky phlegm or anything like that.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No, OK. So it keeps you up at night. Um you mentioned uh the cold symptoms as well, the runny nose. Do you have a <UNIN/> do you have a sore throat at all?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I mean, apart from, I mean the coughing is giving me a sore throat. But it's not like, you know not more than, than that. You know just, just my throat is irritated from coughing. But it's not like, it's not that bad when I swallow or anything.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right. Do you have any uh, <UNIN/> how are your ears? Do you ears feel blocked or?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.They feel OK, actually. Yeah. <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>. Nothing, nothing on the ears.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> No pain, no discharge coming from your ears.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, alright. Um fine. In terms of your breathing, how is your <UNIN/>, how's your chest? Is your breathing more labored?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I don't think so. Like, I guess I get laboured when I'm coughing and I can't breathe. But I, not, yeah, not, I, I don't think so. Not really.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Day to day when you walk around, uh you don't feel breathless do you?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I don't feel restless. No, <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> I feel you know, generally tired.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: So like, yeah, but <UNIN/> not, not anything special with my chest.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any pain in your chest?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No not, not that either.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. You mentioned feeling tired. Um have you felt feverish at all? Have you had a temperature?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um I've been having like, like shivers, even when I'm in, when I'm in bed.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: You know like, when you, when you go to sleep and, and you feel like I I should be warm. But I'm still, still you know, shivering a little bit.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: But I haven't taken my temperature, so I'm not a hundred percent sure if I had a fever. But it feels like I probably did. 'Cause I was just, I was next to my boyfriend. And he was completely warm and totally fine. And I just like couldn't stop shivering. And kept adding more sweaters on, and I was still cold.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. OK. OK. Alright. Um, fine. And in terms of any other symptoms, so have you had any nausea? Have you had any vomiting?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No. No, no nausea. No vomiting. Like, um yeah, <UNIN/> nothing like that.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: How's your appetite?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I mean it's OK. I, at the beginning, like when I was starting to have the <UNIN/>, the <UNIN/>, the coughing and stuff.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I had a little bit of diarrhea. Um but, but it didn't, it didn't cut my appetite or anything. I just like, my stomach wasn't feeling great.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Has that got better now, the diarrhea?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, yeah. It got better. It was only like the first, like it started at the same time as the cough started. And then it stopped. So I thought everything would be fine. But then the cough just kept going.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK fine. Um, any problems with your waterworks at all?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: With my what?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh your <UNIN/> your waterworks, your urine.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Ohh. Uh, no. No no, it's fine.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> you're passing urine OK. You're drinking plenty of fluids, and passing urine OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No. I, I drank loads of water, when I started having the diarrhea. Now that it stopped, I just went back to normal.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, alright. Um in terms of any other thing, do you notice any, any find any skin rashes, or um problems with your muscles or joints?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh <UNIN/> like my, you know when I had the, when I was telling you I had like the, I had chills, and I was really cold. My <UNSURE>muscle </UNSURE> was really hurting.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>Yeah</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. <UNIN/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Sometimes I do pilates. But like, it's hurting me so much at the moment. Um so, to be honest, all I feel like doing is just lying in bed.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right, OK. OK. I'm sorry. That must be very difficult for you. <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, <UNSURE>right</UNSURE>. Especially like in my arms, my legs, like just everywhere basically.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> quite lethargic and weak, you mentioned. <UNSURE>Um</UNSURE>, OK. And um, April are you normally otherwise fit and well?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, pretty much.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Am I normally what?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh fit and well. So do you have any other medical history?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, well I have type two diabetes. And I have quite high blood pressure.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And what do you take for your blood pressure? Any, or what what medications do you take on a regular basis, if you don't mind saying?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um I take <UNIN/> Metformin for the diabetes. And I take Lisinopril for the high blood pressure.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yep.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Zinopril. OK, fine. Any allergies at all, to medications?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No. No allergies.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No, OK. Regarding any family history, is there anything I should be aware of?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh my dad also has type two diabetes. But I think that's it.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, alright. Who's looking after your diabetes? Is there anyone, is there a doctor in a hospital, who looks after your diabetes?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> I just regularly go see a doctor.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, that just checks up on it. Same with the high blood pressure. Like I, I have it under control. And since I've started taking this medication, I've just been like regularly checking that it, it's under control.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right, excellent. And in terms of your social situation, who lives at home with you?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh just, it's just me and my partner.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: lives OK, um fine. Is your partner well at the moment?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah he has none of this. Like he's just going ahead like, like <UNIN/> nothing. Like I was a bit worried that I would pass it to him but, <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> not uh, diarrhea, nothing, fine.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right, OK. <UNSURE>So he</UNSURE>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Go away, he's got away with it, at the moment. OK. And uh, are you working at the moment, April?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, yeah I am working. But the, the first day I skipped. <UNIN/> because I was feeling just too shit. Um, but then, I just felt like had to go back, 'cause I had so much to do. <UNIN/> So I've been going in. But it's not been fun.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No, I can imagine. What is it that you do for work?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I am a developer.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Ohh, so you work in the IT field. OK. <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> IT field. Right, OK. Uh

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNIN/> yeah. Work in IT.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> not too active a job. Uh, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No. Has it been quite stressful recently?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Not more than usual. I don't think it's related to stress. Like I, I don't feel like I've had a particularly hard time at work that way. Um

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: The reason I ask is sometimes

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNIN/> I've been able to take a day off to try and recover. So yeah, I don't think it's related.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Sure. <UNIN/> reason I ask is because sometimes stress can really affect your immune system. Um but uh it's good to know you're you're you're not feeling stressed.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, do you smoke at all, April?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I used to, but I've stopped for about six months now.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Um and what about alcohol?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I mean, yeah I, I don't think I drank that much. Like, I I don't really know how you count the units. So I guess like I don't drink more than like, like, let's say three evenings a week? And I rarely get like properly drunk, or anything.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And what is it that you drink?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Wine, mostly.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>The wine</UNSURE>. How much do you drink on those nights?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I'd say like maybe two or three glasses.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. So um, yeah so you're probably just about under the limit of um, the recommended limit.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Something <UNIN/> think about, just in terms of your blood pressure and diabetes, maybe something that you can maybe cut down on if you can.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah? <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> I should cut down on it.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> really ideally, the the the right answer is to cut down completely. But so in practice I know that's not realistic. So maybe for the first few weeks, why don't you cut down to two glasses a week. And then, one week thereafter

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um and if you are coping OK, then you can maybe try and cut down altogether.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK? Just something for you to think about. Um, right so uh just <UNIN/> as we wrap up really, um April I think based on your story, I think uh essentially I think you're, you're going through a bit of a bit of a viral illness. Um, I don't think there's anything to worry about.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You know you've had a bit of a cough, bit of a runny nose, feeling quite weak and lethargic.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: I'm hoping that, you know, you're probably over the worst of it now. It's been five days. I'm hoping you're maybe going to get better in the next couple of days. It normally lasts for about a week to ten days.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: What, what should I do if it just keeps going on and on? Like if it's still going on in, in say four days?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah, absolutely. So, you know things you can do to help yourself in the meantime is to, you know get some nice, good rest.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Drink plenty of fluids. Keep yourself well-hydrated. You can take regular Paracetamol.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: If you feel like you're still not getting any better in two to three days, it's probably worth coming back to see me again. We can check you over.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And if you are still feeling feverish, um and your cough isn't getting any better, then we may look to give you some antibiotics for your chest. <UNIN/> some of the uh uh common source of infection. Um

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Do you think I should keep going to work? Or do you think I should just

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah so I think you know <UNIN/>, really I think it depends on you. <UNIN/> it's um if you are coughing, then there is a theoretical, you know risk that you're maybe slightly infectious still. So I would say maybe take a day or two off work, if you can.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh and get some good bed rest. Um and maybe think about work early next week.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK. OK. Thank you.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: But um, if your cough isn't getting any better, or your breathing is getting worse, I want you to come back and see me sooner. OK?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK. But otherwise, I don't need to worry.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No no no <UNIN/>, nothing to worry about otherwise.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK. Alright. Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Well, have a good day. Appreciate it.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Thank you. Bye!
